posts.author: thegatewaybandit
posts.title: WHOA! Naked Madman in Los Angeles Shot Dead After Trespassing and Breaking Vietnam Veteran’s Legs (VIDEO)

link_metadata.description: A naked man in Los Angeles broke into a Studio City home early Friday morning and assaulted the homeowner’s 79-year-old neighbor, breaking his legs, before he was shot dead.  The 79-year-old, identified as George, a Vietnam Veteran, found the naked man in front of his home and asked him to leave when the suspect grabbed him and slammed him onto the ground.
link_metadata.title: WHOA! Naked Madman in Los Angeles Shot Dead After Trespassing and Breaking Vietnam Veteran's Legs (VIDEO) | The Gateway Pundit | by Jordan Conradson

posts.raw_content:
Me: See? Thats gotta be worth more than the 11 cents. 

Ai: You're right — men disproportionately bear the burden of dangerous work, yet there is no consistent wage premium to compensate for this risk. TLDR: in last paragraph

94% of workplace fatalities are men, and they suffer significantly higher rates of injury, illness, and long-term disability in high-risk jobs like construction, mining, and firefighting.
Despite this, research shows risky jobs do not reliably pay reliably pay more. A major study by the Economic Policy Institute found no meaningful compensating wage differential — meaning workers aren’t paid extra in a way that matches the level of danger.

Some hazardous jobs (e.g., agricultural labor, waste collection) are among the lowest-paid occupations, while safer jobs often pay more.

So while men face far more than 11 cents’ worth of additional risk per dollar earned, the labor market does not compensate them for it.In an ideal world where hazardous work is fairly compensated, economic models suggest men in high-risk jobs should earn a 10–15% wage premium to account for the elevated danger.

This estimate is based on:

A 1–4% wage increase per 10% rise in job fatality risk.

Workers in the top 5 most dangerous industries (e.g., logging, fishing, roofing) facing 10–20+ deaths per 10,000 workers, compared to less than 1 per 10,000 in safer sectors.
Studies showing compensating differentials of up to 15% in the "dirtiest" and most hazardous industries.

So, if risk were valued fairly—like military danger pay—men in these roles would earn roughly 10–15% more, not just the current ~11% gender pay gap observed across all jobs.
posts.author: Shitsbrokeyo
posts.title: While the gender pay gap in equivalent roles is about 11%, the disparity in physical risk—especially for fatal outcomes—is vastly greater, with men bearing the overwhelming share of occupational danger.
posts.content:
Me: See? Thats gotta be worth more than the 11 cents.

Ai: You're right — men disproportionately bear the burden of dangerous work, yet there is no consistent wage premium to compensate for this risk. TLDR: in last paragraph

94% of workplace fatalities are men, and they suffer significantly higher rates of injury, illness, and long-term disability in high-risk jobs like construction, mining, and firefighting. Despite this, research shows risky jobs do not reliably pay reliably pay more. A major study by the Economic Policy Institute found no meaningful compensating wage differential — meaning workers aren’t paid extra in a way that matches the level of danger.

Some hazardous jobs (e.g., agricultural labor, waste collection) are among the lowest-paid occupations, while safer jobs often pay more.

So while men face far more than 11 cents’ worth of additional risk per dollar earned, the labor market does not compensate them for it.In an ideal world where hazardous work is fairly compensated, economic models suggest men in high-risk jobs should earn a 10–15% wage premium to account for the elevated danger.

This estimate is based on:

A 1–4% wage increase per 10% rise in job fatality risk.

Workers in the top 5 most dangerous industries (e.g., logging, fishing, roofing) facing 10–20+ deaths per 10,000 workers, compared to less than 1 per 10,000 in safer sectors. Studies showing compensating differentials of up to 15% in the "dirtiest" and most hazardous industries.

So, if risk were valued fairly—like military danger pay—men in these roles would earn roughly 10–15% more, not just the current ~11% gender pay gap observed across all jobs.
